bibl.title: Moy Share Park v. Henry M. White. Return
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: Filed in the United States District Court
In the Matter of the Application of Moy Share Park for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Hugh C. Todd, Esq., Attorney for petitioner.
Robert C. Saunders, Attorney for United States.
The petitioner is held under an order of deportation issued by the Secretary of Labor. He seeks discharge under writ of habeas corpus, on the ground that he was denied a fair hearing.
He is not sustained by the record.

Sec. 25 of the Chinese Exclusion Act; Comp. St. 1913, Sec. 4274, provides that the decision of the appropriate immigration officers, if adverse to admission, is final, unless reversed on appeal to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, and courts have no jurisdiction unless a fair trial was denied.
That there was evidence supporting the contention of the immigration officers is conceded by the brief of petitioner filed before the Secretary of Labor on appeal. Counsel say:

"With respect to the rather formidable array of discrepancies mentioned * * We can only call attention to the fact that quite as formidable array of agreements might be enumerated, and perhaps the one list, if merely weighed against the other, taking no other favorable or unfavorable features into consideration, might be found to more than counterbalance * *."

Without going into an analysis of the testimony, it is sufficient to say that there is testimony supporting the decision of the Immigration Board, and where there is testimony, the court is without jurisdiction. Ex parte Ng Kwack Kang, 233 Fed. 478.
